subject: wsgi: Allow workers to gracefully exit
messages:
[{'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-08-21 05:08:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-08-21 15:42:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-08-21 16:11:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

I'm a little curious about what will happen to connections that are in the socket's completed connection queue but we haven't accepted yet :-/"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-08-21 21:12:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2020-08-26 17:27:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

(8 comments)

The code in wsgi is great, and allows troublesome workers to be individually targeted in a graceful way.

I found this:

https://gist.github.com/teh/1126302

I was testing with this:

https://gist.github.com/clayg/eea76851a440a851196627348012295f

I saw that I could send USR/HUP to a worker and he'd stay alive as long as I was connected, and my request would finish successfully.

If I had only one worker after sending the signal new connections would get an error:

    socket.error: [Errno 111] ECONNREFUSED

... until the client holding the zombie worker finished and the parent restarted it.

If I had *more* than one worker killing just one wouldn't interrupt connections at all!

I have a big reservation about exposing the kill_child_pids command.  Hopefully we can merge/squash my follow up:  https://review.opendev.org/748281"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-09-01 17:39:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2020-09-03 13:19:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

:'("}]

node information in the sample node-related notifications
reflect the latest versions of the notification payloads.
Which includes the driver_internal_info recently added to
version 1.16 of NodeSetProvisionStatePayload.

Change-Id: I87fb443ff393a2a58f9d19a9011df062f85af3af
Story: #2008054
Task: #40771

commit_message:
Update nodes in notifications documentation

This updates the notifications documentation so that the
node information in the sample node-related notifications
reflect the latest versions of the notification payloads.
Which includes the driver_internal_info recently added to
version 1.16 of NodeSetProvisionStatePayload.

Change-Id: I87fb443ff393a2a58f9d19a9011df062f85af3af
Story: #2008054
Task: #40771

messages:
[{'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2020-09-02 15:53:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4264, 'date': '2020-09-03 06:04:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Thank you, this looks good to me.'}, {'account_id': 4264, 'date': '2020-09-03 06:05:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

integration tests fail, because of aodh was not completely installed.'}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2020-09-03 06:10:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> integration tests fail, because of aodh was not completely installed.

This is a cyclic issue. This patch can't merge without https://review.opendev.org/#/c/749480/ merging first and that can't merge without this as the tests are failing without this.

I hate the way tempest plugins work:/ 

I guess https://review.opendev.org/#/c/749480/ has to disable the tests or may be make the jobs non-voting to merge."}, {'account_id': 4264, 'date': '2020-09-03 06:14:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

the other patch fails because sphinx-pdf build fails. It doesn't look like a cyclic dep for me."}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2020-09-03 06:19:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

pdf build issue is an additional one.

Check the failures in that without this patch as Depends-On there.

https://storage.gra.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_952/749480/2/check/telemetry-dsvm-integration/95266d7/job-output.txt'}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2020-09-03 08:17:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2020-09-03 09:13:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2020-09-03 09:14:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Looks like jobs are passing here. No clue what has changed:/'}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2020-09-03 10:25:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

We can merge this one I guess.'}, {'account_id': 4264, 'date': '2020-09-03 11:59:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
[trivial] remove emacs config from devstack script

It could cause issues during execution, and in general ide or
editors specific config should not be kept here but in a specific
config file.

Change-Id: I4fbf7c6d00f2ba19a860d4c39cd882f541ff0600

commit_message:
Replace tz.UTC with dateutil.tz.tzutc()

As discussed in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/742477/, this patch
replaces the use of `tz.UTC` with `dateutil.tz.tzutc()`

Also add python-dateutil to requirements.txt, using the same minimum
version as several other OpenStack projects, including nova.

Change-Id: I4da9e8854a571058e48c2f51c1d340bc135cfe2b
(cherry picked from commit b7abb9bb698d4d391da7f69ca983164f51d9a567)

commit_message:
Replace tz.UTC with dateutil.tz.tzutc()

As discussed in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/742477/, this patch
replaces the use of `tz.UTC` with `dateutil.tz.tzutc()`

Also add python-dateutil to requirements.txt, using the same minimum
version as several other OpenStack projects, including nova.

Change-Id: I4da9e8854a571058e48c2f51c1d340bc135cfe2b
(cherry picked from commit b7abb9bb698d4d391da7f69ca983164f51d9a567)

the floating ip port forwarding functionality.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/747299/

Closes-Bug: #1877447

commit_message:
[ovn]: Enable port forwarding in neutron service plugins

NeutronServicePlugins needs to include port_forwarding in order to support
the floating ip port forwarding functionality.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/747299/
Change-Id: I27ac0a536624f5461809df771a58a6e57fec0661
Closes-Bug: #1877447
Signed-off-by: Flavio Fernandes <flaviof@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 40fa5244c279952baf429ffcb95e632f0db32c52)

commit_message:
[ovn]: port forwarding -- functional tests for maintenance task

This is a subset of the changes for implementing the floating IP
port forwarding feature in neutron, using OVN as the backend.

This changeset adds functional tests in maintenance task to ensure
that floating ips as well as port forwarding are properly handled.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/741303/
Change-Id: I0671ed8d73ca8c0e3ba4aded81f395e20957d598
Partially-implements: ovn/port_forwarding
Partial-Bug: #1877447
(cherry picked from commit a183400eaef93f04767fd398f56522435523e198)

commit_message:
[ovn]: port forwarding -- feature support under ovn_db_sync

This is a subset of the changes for implementing the floating IP
port forwarding feature in neutron, using OVN as the backend.

This changeset updates ovn_db_sync utility and its tests to
ensure that floating ip port forwarding can be repaired.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/741303/
Change-Id: I7a158173252e73e081914f242133634c41de7999
Partially-implements: ovn/port_forwarding
Partial-Bug: #1877447
(cherry picked from commit 361b4853180b84b1d8ba38a6967de4c254aacb0c)

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/747299/7 : SUCCESS in 1h 48m 13s'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2020-08-26 01:40:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

> > This breaks the rule of the stable branches:
 > > https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/stable-branches.html#active-maintenance
 > 
 > Hi Liu,
 > 
 > > not allowing backports of new features, new dependencies,
 > > or backward incompatible changes
 > 
 > Port forwarding is not a new feature for Ussuri or even Train.
 > We were careful not to introduce any new dependencies or
 > changes to the API. There should be no issues with backward
 > compatibility. Is there a specific change that you see as an issue?

IMHO, this is new to the OVN backend. New features will need some dev cycles to make it more robust, this should be the main reason why it is not allowed. Otherwise the new stuff will expand the maintaince scope for the stable branches. These rules say

"""
Some types of changes are completely forbidden:

New features

...
"""
I did not try this, but again we should not rush to make this to the stable branch before it has a large quantities of real users. Until then, the issue maybe not so easily to expose.

Alright, but the decision-making still lies in the stable maintenance team. The rule doc also says
"""
Proposed backports breaking any of the above guidelines can be discussed as exception requests on the openstack-discuss list (prefix with [stable]) where the stable maintenance core team will have the final say.

Each backported commit proposed to Gerrit should be reviewed and +2ed by two project-specific stable maintenance team members before it is approved. Where a team member has backported a fix, a single other +2 is sufficient for approval.

If unsure about the technical details of a given fix, project-specific stable maintenance team members should consult with the appropriate project core reviewers for a more detailed technical review.
"""'}, {'account_id': 11952, 'date': '2020-08-26 14:21:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Workflow-1

> > > This breaks the rule of the stable branches:
 > > > https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/stable-branches.html#active-maintenance
 > >
 > > Hi Liu,
 > >
 > > > not allowing backports of new features, new dependencies,
 > > > or backward incompatible changes
 > >
 > > Port forwarding is not a new feature for Ussuri or even Train.
 > > We were careful not to introduce any new dependencies or
 > > changes to the API. There should be no issues with backward
 > > compatibility. Is there a specific change that you see as an
 > issue?
 > 
 > IMHO, this is new to the OVN backend. New features will need some
 > dev cycles to make it more robust, this should be the main reason
 > why it is not allowed. Otherwise the new stuff will expand the
 > maintaince scope for the stable branches. These rules say
 > 
 > """
 > Some types of changes are completely forbidden:
 > 
 > New features
 > 
 > ...
 > """
 > I did not try this, but again we should not rush to make this to
 > the stable branch before it has a large quantities of real users.
 > Until then, the issue maybe not so easily to expose.
 > 
 > Alright, but the decision-making still lies in the stable
 > maintenance team. The rule doc also says
 > """
 > Proposed backports breaking any of the above guidelines can be
 > discussed as exception requests on the openstack-discuss list
 > (prefix with [stable]) where the stable maintenance core team will
 > have the final say.
 > 
 > Each backported commit proposed to Gerrit should be reviewed and
 > +2ed by two project-specific stable maintenance team members before
 > it is approved. Where a team member has backported a fix, a single
 > other +2 is sufficient for approval.
 > 
 > If unsure about the technical details of a given fix,
 > project-specific stable maintenance team members should consult
 > with the appropriate project core reviewers for a more detailed
 > technical review.
 > """

Sounds reasonable, Liu. I appreciate you bringing this up and will follow up with a plan that does not break any rules.'}, {'account_id': 11952, 'date': '2020-08-31 16:06:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 11952, 'date': '2020-08-31 16:11:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: -Workflow

@Liu: Update: I'm back from PTO and will be actively talking to the Neutron stable maintainers about this. 

The fact that no API changes take place with this change and that they are all OVN related makes me think we should be okay to backport. But I am respectfully interested on what my Neutron gurus --like you-- decide on this."}, {'account_id': 11952, 'date': '2020-09-01 08:47:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2020-09-01 09:18:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

commit_message:
[ovn]: port forwarding -- core changes

This is a subset of the changes for implementing the floating IP
port forwarding feature in neutron, using OVN as the backend.

This changeset covers the core implementation for portforwarding/drivers/ovn,
mech_driver, ovn-router as well as a subset of tests.

Port forwarding support in ovn_db_sync is not included here to facilitate review.
That, as well as all other supporting changes, are under the ovn/port_forwarding topic:
https://review.opendev.org/#/q/topic:ovn/port_forwarding+(status:open+OR+status:merged)

Conflicts:
devstack/ovn-local.conf.sample
neutron/common/ovn/extensions.py
neutron/tests/unit/common/ovn/test_utils.py
zuul.d/tempest-multinode.yaml

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/747280/
Partially-implements: ovn/port_forwarding
Partial-Bug: #1877447

Change-Id: I019fe11ac1ddcf2304f3f144c62d52667fc11dce

commit_message:
[ovn]: port forwarding -- IDL changes

This is a subset of the changes for implementing the floating IP
port forwarding feature in neutron, using OVN as the backend.

This changeset covers the additions to northbound api needed for
handling load balancer entries created on behalf of port forwarding.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/729354/
Change-Id: I7d0aa51468dbd2c298395c3dccd8f222e87032d8
Partially-implements: ovn/port_forwarding
Partial-Bug: #1877447
(cherry picked from commit 597bb0d1877f92f9300d7d337bb9920ac82cab9a)

commit_message:
[ovn]: port forwarding -- Functional test for IDL changes

This is a subset of the changes for implementing the floating IP
port forwarding feature in neutron, using OVN as the backend.

This changeset introduces functional tests for the IDL functions
added to the NB API for supporting port forwarding.

Note: The backport removes the usage of the selection_fields
column in the load balancer table, because it is new in OVN
and have no real role in the test itself.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/741000/
Change-Id: I01f54ea4a21eb635f0bf87a15694929ed1f3a643
Partially-implements: ovn/port_forwarding
Partial-Bug: #1877447
(cherry picked from commit 605de6d96854767edd6ed5a1512e3e46b7b0c311)

commit_message:
port_forwarding: extend support for OVN usage

This commit adds possibility to configure fip port_forwarding
service plugin and l3 extension with devstack plugin for OVN.

Since OVN uses API workers, this change also introduces the
callbacks necessary in pf_plugin, so events related to port
forwarding are sent using neutron_lib callbacks registry.

Conflicts:
neutron/tests/unit/services/portforwarding/test_pf_plugin.py

Related-Bug: #1877447
Change-Id: I8124fac13bf4d802d232e8b3976e6a2cebc72106
(cherry picked from commit 102c442bcfa39074787e3292818880ecf238ac61)

commit_message:
port_forwarding: extend support for OVN usage (cont.)

This is a follow up from commit 102c442bcfa39074787e3292818880ecf238ac61

The call to resources_rpc.ResourcesPushRpcApi() will fail in situations
where RPC is not available. That is the case for neutron_ovn_db_sync_util.

The changes here will only set push_api if any of the configured service
plugins need it. This is a behavior similar to what is done for the QOS
plugin.

Note: This change also cherry picks changes from gerrit change
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/736242/ in order to address the following
pep8 issue:

./neutron/tests/unit/services/portforwarding/test_pf_plugin.py:524:9:
  N328  Use assertTrue(observed) instead of assertEqual(True, observed)
        self.assertEqual(
        ^

Related-Bug: #1877447
Change-Id: I3f2e18fabf4556cd708c6e544b5aaf37f72b44df
(cherry picked from commit eb46081150a4ca4e2007cabfcadd134cbc85435e)
(cherry picked from commit 8913461aa9896e00a011693d20a42188766a8348)

commit_message:
[ovn]: port forwarding -- extend support for OVN usage (cont.)

This is a follow up from commit eb46081150a4ca4e2007cabfcadd134cbc85435e
This is a follow up from commit 93663aa614e5f40782c3f89fa0a61cd33277a6e9

In order to be used by functional tests -- or anything that does not use
stevedore that can map from "ovn-router" value -- pf_plugin also needs to
recognize "neutron.services.ovn_l3.plugin.OVNL3RouterPlugin" as a way for
specifying the OVN L3 service plugin.

Change-Id: I4227cc3ceb2a17f40df86dadd71d99198b6b26e9
Related-Bug: #1877447
(cherry picked from commit 61bf68de3185c48363a6c6c9187773368152ffdd)

commit_message:
[ovn]: port forwarding -- documentation

This is a subset of the changes for implementing the floating IP
port forwarding feature in neutron, using OVN as the backend.

This changeset covers the documentation updates for the feature,
as well as a high-level description of how OVN implements it.

Partially-implements: ovn/port_forwarding
Partially-implements: blueprint portforwarding-description
Partial-Bug: #1877447

Conflicts:
	doc/source/ovn/gaps.rst

Change-Id: I2059a011f650dd7070a74dc6107aab2b15ca7104
(cherry picked from commit e2060a2f0b317aadc41443accfbdc5cafae44f44)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-08-13 08:31:27.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: action providers

Change-Id: Ic9108c9293731b3576081c75f2786e1156ba0ccd
'}, {'created': '2020-08-13 09:09:00.000000000', 'message': "Add main entities related to action providers

* This patch adds the base infrastructure for the new concept
  that we call Action Providers. It will allow to refactor
  Mistral in a way that all action management will be encapsulated
  with action providers. For example, Mistral Engine needs to
  schedule actions while processing a workflow. Now it has to
  access DB itself to find an action definition (meta info about
  what this action is, like python class, input params etc.),
  then prepare input parameters, validate parameters and send a
  message to an executor to run it. In many other places, Mistral
  also directly access DB to fetch an action definition. It's
  not flexible because we assume that definitions of Mistral
  actions must always be stored in DB. The concept of an Action
  Provider allows moving away from that limitation. A particular
  implementation of the ActionProvider interface can store action
  definitions in any suitable way, even fetching them using
  various transport protocols like AMQP, HTTP, TCP, or anything
  else. An action provider may also generate action definitions
  dynamically, like creating wrappers around a set of operating
  system commands. But for the rest of the system it won't matter
  what happens inside action providers. All details will be
  hidden behind a unified interface.
* Added ActionDescriptor interface and its convenience base
  abstract implementation. ActionDescriptor is an entity
  representing an action before it's instantiated. It carries
  the most important meta information about an action like name,
  description, input parameters etc. It is also responsible for
  validating action input parameters and instantiating a real
  action.
* Added PythonActionDescriptor which represents a regular action
  written as a Python class.
* Added CompositeActionProvider that delegates calls find() and
  find_all() to a collection of other action providers.
* Minor style changes.

Partially implements: bp/mistral-action-providers

Change-Id: Ic9108c9293731b3576081c75f2786e1156ba0ccd
"}, {'created': '2020-08-13 09:09:44.000000000', 'message': "Add main entities related to action providers

* This patch adds the base infrastructure for the new concept
  that we call Action Providers. It will allow to refactor
  Mistral in a way that all action management will be encapsulated
  with action providers. For example, Mistral Engine needs to
  schedule actions while processing a workflow. Now it has to
  access DB itself to find an action definition (meta info about
  what this action is, like python class, input params etc.),
  then prepare input parameters, validate parameters and send a
  message to an executor to run it. In many other places, Mistral
  also directly access DB to fetch an action definition. It's
  not flexible because we assume that definitions of Mistral
  actions must always be stored in DB. The concept of an Action
  Provider allows moving away from that limitation. A particular
  implementation of the ActionProvider interface can store action
  definitions in any suitable way, even fetching them using
  various transport protocols like AMQP, HTTP, TCP, or anything
  else. An action provider may also generate action definitions
  dynamically, like creating wrappers around a set of operating
  system commands. But for the rest of the system it won't matter
  what happens inside action providers. All details will be
  hidden behind a unified interface.
* Added ActionDescriptor interface and its convenience base
  abstract implementation. ActionDescriptor is an entity
  representing an action before it's instantiated. It carries
  the most important meta information about an action like name,
  description, input parameters etc. It is also responsible for
  validating action input parameters and instantiating a real
  action.
* Added PythonActionDescriptor which represents a regular action
  written as a Python class.
* Added CompositeActionProvider that delegates calls find() and
  find_all() to a collection of other action providers.
* Minor style changes.

Partially implements: bp/mistral-action-providers

Change-Id: Ic9108c9293731b3576081c75f2786e1156ba0ccd

commit_message:
Add main entities related to action providers

* This patch adds the base infrastructure for the new concept
  that we call Action Providers. It will allow to refactor
  Mistral in a way that all action management will be encapsulated
  with action providers. For example, Mistral Engine needs to
  schedule actions while processing a workflow. Now it has to
  access DB itself to find an action definition (meta info about
  what this action is, like python class, input params etc.),
  then prepare input parameters, validate parameters and send a
  message to an executor to run it. In many other places, Mistral
  also directly access DB to fetch an action definition. It's
  not flexible because we assume that definitions of Mistral
  actions must always be stored in DB. The concept of an Action
  Provider allows moving away from that limitation. A particular
  implementation of the ActionProvider interface can store action
  definitions in any suitable way, even fetching them using
  various transport protocols like AMQP, HTTP, TCP, or anything
  else. An action provider may also generate action definitions
  dynamically, like creating wrappers around a set of operating
  system commands. But for the rest of the system it won't matter
  what happens inside action providers. All details will be
  hidden behind a unified interface.
* Added ActionDescriptor interface and its convenience base
  abstract implementation. ActionDescriptor is an entity
  representing an action before it's instantiated. It carries
  the most important meta information about an action like name,
  description, input parameters etc. It is also responsible for
  validating action input parameters and instantiating a real
  action.
* Added PythonActionDescriptor which represents a regular action
  written as a Python class.
* Added CompositeActionProvider that delegates calls find() and
  find_all() to a collection of other action providers.
* Minor style changes.

Partially implements: bp/mistral-action-providers

Change-Id: Ic9108c9293731b3576081c75f2786e1156ba0ccd

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-04-12 09:16:49.000000000', 'message': 'Make subnode IPs known to all Swift hosts

Doing this allows us to build a ring that uses all subnodes for storage.
This info will be reused both on the primary nodes (running the Swift
proxy) and the subnodes (running Swift storage services) to build local
rings.

Change-Id: I0dcadaefc4751568f029498c316914b270c06386

'}, {'created': '2016-04-15 12:23:23.000000000', 'message': 'Use subnodes for Swift storage nodes in a multinode setup

This change uses the subnode for Swift storage nodes, while running the
Swift proxy on the primary node.

However, when running devstack on the primary node we need a working
Swift cluster (because some images will be uploaded then and later used
in Tempest), and therefore Swift storage services have to be running on
the subnode already.

This is done by running devstack one time on the subnode before the
primary node, but only for Swift storage services. This is achieved by
doing the following:

1. Disable all services
2. Enable only SWIFT_STORAGE_SERVICES (s-account,s-container, s-object)
3. Temporary move local.conf to tmp.local.conf (because it contains a
NOVA_CONF section and devstack would fail because Nova is not enabled)
4. Run ./stack.sh
5. Put local.conf back in place, and enable previously defined services

The subnode will be deployed again after the primary node is deployed,
now adding other services like Nova.

The correct behavior can be verified by comparing the storage service
logs on the primary and subnode; requests are served by the storage
services on the subnode and the proxy on the primary node.

Change-Id: I0dcadaefc4751568f029498c316914b270c06386
'}, {'created': '2016-04-15 14:22:03.000000000', 'message': 'Use subnodes for Swift storage nodes in a multinode setup

This change uses the subnode for Swift storage nodes, while running the
Swift proxy on the primary node.

3. Temporary move local.conf to tmp.local.conf (because it contains a

4. Run ./stack.sh
5. Put local.conf back in place, and enable previously defined services

The subnode will be deployed again after the primary node is deployed,
now adding other services like Nova.

The parameters SWIFT_LOOPBACK_DISK_SIZE and SWIFT_MAX_FILE_SIZE need to
be set manually; they are too low because neither g-api nor tempest is
enabled on the subnode and therefore devstack chooses a lower value (see
devstack/lib/swift).

The correct behavior can be verified by comparing the storage service
logs on the primary and subnode; requests are served by the storage
services on the subnode and the proxy on the primary node.

commit_message:
Use subnodes for Swift storage nodes in a multinode setup

This change uses the subnode for Swift storage nodes, while running the
Swift proxy on the primary node.

However, when running devstack on the primary node we need a working
Swift cluster (because some images will be uploaded then and later used
in Tempest), and therefore Swift storage services have to be running on
the subnode already.

This is done by running devstack one time on the subnode before the
primary node, but only for Swift storage services. This is achieved by
doing the following:

1. Disable all services
2. Enable only SWIFT_STORAGE_SERVICES (s-account,s-container, s-object)
3. Temporary move local.conf to tmp.local.conf (because it contains a
NOVA_CONF section and devstack would fail because Nova is not enabled)
4. Run ./stack.sh
5. Put local.conf back in place, and enable previously defined services

The subnode will be deployed again after the primary node is deployed,
now adding other services like Nova.

The parameters SWIFT_LOOPBACK_DISK_SIZE and SWIFT_MAX_FILE_SIZE need to
be set manually; they are too low because neither g-api nor tempest is
enabled on the subnode and therefore devstack chooses a lower value (see
devstack/lib/swift).

The correct behavior can be verified by comparing the storage service
logs on the primary and subnode; requests are served by the storage
services on the subnode and the proxy on the primary node.

Change-Id: I0dcadaefc4751568f029498c316914b270c06386

I couldn't make the tests on master fail:

- gettext_ is monkey patched in test/__init__ line 38, so I don't see how the locale makes a difference to testing.

- what would msg need to be for the replace() to raise a unicode error?"}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2016-07-08 21:01:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

so `nosetests -s test.unit.proxy.test_server` fails for me with this patch same as the gate, but the gate seems to truncate the log message length?

    HTTP PERF: 0.00852 seconds to GET 127.0.0.1:47781 /sda1/1/a/4_vc_ascii?prefix=00f4_o_non_ascii¬£/)
    proxy ERROR: ERROR 500 Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/eventlet/wsgi.py", line 481, in handle_one_response
        result = self.application(self.environ, start_response)
      File "/vagrant/swift/swift/container/server.py", line 614, in __call__
        self.logger.info(log_message)
      File "/usr/lib/python2.7/logging/__init__.py", line 1433, in info
        self.logger.info(msg, *args, **kwargs)
      File "/usr/lib/python2.7/logging/__init__.py", line 1152, in info
        self._log(INFO, msg, args, **kwargs)
      File "/vagrant/swift/test/unit/__init__.py", line 528, in _log
        super(FakeLogger, self)._log(level, msg, *args, **kwargs)
      File "/usr/lib/python2.7/logging/__init__.py", line 1271, in _log
        self.handle(record)
      File "/vagrant/swift/test/unit/__init__.py", line 632, in handle
        print(self.formatter.format(record))
      File "/vagrant/swift/test/unit/__init__.py", line 619, in format
        return msg.encode('utf-8').replace('
    ', '\n')
    UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc2 From Container Server 127.0.0.1:47781/sda1 (txn: tx07f10b287f7240129b772-005780126c)

You can of course fix/prevent the error with the guard before the encode:

    diff --git a/test/unit/__init__.py b/test/unit/__init__.py
    index 4f2dbea..3b7ab4d 100644
    --- a/test/unit/__init__.py
    +++ b/test/unit/__init__.py
    @@ -616,7 +616,9 @@ class DebugSwiftLogFormatter(utils.SwiftLogFormatter):
     
         def format(self, record):
             msg = super(DebugSwiftLogFormatter, self).format(record)
    -        return msg.encode('utf-8').replace('#012', '\n')
    +        if isinstance(msg, unicode):
    +            msg = msg.encode('utf-8')
    +        return msg.replace('#012', '\n')
     
     
     class DebugLogger(FakeLogger):

... but it's not clear to me why that matters/works in-so-far as the inconsistent typing or why replace cares?

Also passes for me without any change on master, but I probably need to figureout how to build/install the translations (*.mo) into my dev environment?'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2017-12-18 05:01:41.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Jenkins with the following votes:

* Verified-1 by Jenkins (3)
'}, {'account_id': 6968, 'date': '2020-09-03 12:05:00.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2016-07-08 06:35:27.000000000', 'message': 'Make verbose unicode test output working

Currently tests will fail with an exception and subsequent timeouts if
one runs tests with a non-default locale and enables verbose output.
This is due to the fact that the catched output is not encoded properly
before printing it, and therefore raises an unicode error.

With this patch applied one can run something like this now:

 export LANG="de_DE.UTF-8"
 nosetests -s test.unit.proxy.controllers.test_obj

Change-Id: I00ac45429a09462df6c4407a925395097a1c46d0
'}]
commit_message:
Make verbose unicode test output working

Currently tests will fail with an exception and subsequent timeouts if
one runs tests with a non-default locale and enables verbose output.
This is due to the fact that the catched output is not encoded properly
before printing it, and therefore raises an unicode error.

With this patch applied one can run something like this now:

 export LANG="de_DE.UTF-8"
 nosetests -s test.unit.proxy.controllers.test_obj

Change-Id: I00ac45429a09462df6c4407a925395097a1c46d0

subject: Refactor locale tests and fix unicode issue

This all looked good until I tried to run swift-init with a French locale. Unfortunately where we use print, the message is now unicode with non-ascii characters and the print raises a UnicodeError when coercing to a string because it will default to using an ascii encoding. I guess the original test would have caught that since it actually performed the print.

See http://paste.openstack.org/show/508903/

However, I am unable to reproduce the error in the test_locale.py context, so I am confused :/'}, {'account_id': 6968, 'date': '2016-06-08 13:29:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

@Alistair: thx for checking, I'll look into this."}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2016-06-08 13:59:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Alistair, you used a French locale, but with what encoding? You may need to run

 sudo locale-gen fr_FR.UTF-8

to actually have a French locale that knows UTF-8. I know I had to.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2016-06-08 15:24:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

Tim's tip worked for me:

  swift@anc-vm-10:~/swift$ sudo locale-gen fr_FR.UTF-8
Generating locales...
  fr_FR.UTF-8... up-to-date
Generation complete.
swift@anc-vm-10:~/swift$ export LC_ALL=fr_FR.UTF-8
swift@anc-vm-10:~/swift$ export LANGUAGE=fr_FR.UTF-8
swift@anc-vm-10:~/swift$ export SWIFT_LOCALEDIR=/home/swift/swift/swift/locale
swift@anc-vm-10:~/swift$ msgfmt /home/swift/swift/swift/locale/fr/LC_MESSAGES/swift.po -o /home/swift/swift/swift/locale/fr/LC_MESSAGES/swift.mo

I verified that this does address the linked bug report - remove objects dir from one node, run the reconstructor, see the exception raised on master, switch to this branch, repeat and the translated message is logged:

  Succ√®s de Rsync pour /srv/1/node/sdb1/objects/30/66d dans 127.0.0.1::object6040/sdb4/objects/30 (0.148)"}, {'account_id': 6968, 'date': '2016-06-08 15:47:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6968, 'date': '2016-06-08 16:02:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

With the SwiftStreamWriter it will now also work without setting an explicit UTF-8 encoding. We could remove that part again if you think it is no longer needed.

Latest patchset includes the old tests again, to ensure we still cover print() output.'}, {'account_id': 6968, 'date': '2016-06-08 16:20:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6968, 'date': '2016-06-08 16:22:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Back to patchset #2, the one without hacking around sys.stdout. Seems to be the most lightweight solution if the encoding is properly set.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-06-08 20:23:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified+1

- gate-tempest-dsvm-neutron-identity-v3-only-full-nv http://logs.openstack.org/50/323950/4/check/gate-tempest-dsvm-neutron-identity-v3-only-full-nv/f5644b9/ : SUCCESS in 54m 11s (non-voting)
- gate-grenade-dsvm http://logs.openstack.org/50/323950/4/check/gate-grenade-dsvm/20ee72d/ : SUCCESS in 46m 48s
- gate-swift-dsvm-functional http://logs.openstack.org/50/323950/4/check/gate-swift-dsvm-functional/66667b3/ : SUCCESS in 25m 06s
- gate-swift-tox-bandit http://logs.openstack.org/50/323950/4/check/gate-swift-tox-bandit/748610f/ : SUCCESS in 54s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2016-06-12 13:52:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2016-07-06 00:35:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I think lots of places we deal with utf-8 bytestrings on the wire or read from disk - maybe via object metadata.

we can safely assume gettext returns utf-8 - but aside from device entries in the ring - I think we *mainly* try to interpolate utf-8 strings into log messages (swob.Request tries real hard to keep the environ bytestrings in utf-8).

However, when you try to interpolate utf-8 bytestrings into unicode message templates it'll blow up - which we *probably* would catch, we monkey patch gettext test/__init__.py?"}, {'account_id': 6968, 'date': '2016-07-06 08:06:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)

@Clay: so your idea is to make logging more exception-safe?'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2016-07-06 19:51:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

So I am mainly concerned about not handling our mock for gettext_ in test/__init__.py

I had thought simply making that change would expose a bunch of errors where we try to interpolate utf-8 bytestring arguments that we read from the filesystem into the (now) unicode strings returned from our gettext_ - but it seemed like everything worked.

But then again... maybe we just don't have good tests for non-ascii chars on the file system [2]

1. https://gist.github.com/clayg/904091bcb2f4b223cdf531e9bb75f9b0
2. https://gist.github.com/clayg/f21a614c1d5ba1e31899fd8a72b433af"}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2016-09-12 20:52:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

I'm trying to remember what I was not happy with.

I noticed that if I apply both of my gists [1] [2]- tests fail

I think this might be a step in the right direction tho - but we should recognize that a bunch of file system api's in py2 return utf-8 - I have it on good authority that py3 should continue to move all of this to unicode.

If we *only* fix the test/__init__.py gettext function to return unicode like the real one [1] I think I'll be pretty happy.  I'd probably be even happier if there was some way to just make unittests enforce LC_ALL=C before we go and try to assert an error messages and *not* monkey patch the gettext function in unittests?

maybe we need an "assertTranslatedMessageOnlyIfDefaultLocale" or something?

1. monkey patch the monkey patch of our unittest gettext function so that it decodes utf-8 like the real thing does after this change - https://gist.github.com/clayg/904091bcb2f4b223cdf531e9bb75f9b0
2. update a few existing tests to ensure some utf-8 bytestrings from disk get interpolated into the resulting unicode translation template - https://gist.github.com/clayg/f21a614c1d5ba1e31899fd8a72b433af'}, {'account_id': 9576, 'date': '2016-09-13 22:28:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2016-09-14 21:30:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

I like this approach "more unicode everywhere!" - but I think this patch needs more work.  The patched gettext in unittests not returning unicode like the real gettext function is going to bite us.  I think there's a few bugs waiting to happen in the diskfile once we start to interpolate bytestrings from os functions like listdir into unicode translated messages from our fixed gettext - so it'd be nice if unittests did the same thing as the real gettext function so we could surface and fix bugs more easily.'}, {'account_id': 6968, 'date': '2020-09-03 12:04:40.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

There is an issue if someone uses a non-english locale, that includes
non US-ASCII chars. In that case appending a unicode argument to a
string fails with an error. The problem is the mix of str and unicode
objects and the handling when printing them using sys.stdout/stderr.

An inherited StreamWriter class has been added that ensures str objects
are not modified while unicode objects will be utf-8 encoded.

This patch also improves the existing test, covering a few more
different cases with english and non-english locales. The last test
currently fails on master with an UnicodeDecodeError; this is fixed by
the gettext decoding.

Closes-Bug: 1580678

commit_message:
Refactor locale tests and fix unicode issue

There is an issue if someone uses a non-english locale, that includes
non US-ASCII chars. In that case appending a unicode argument to a
string fails with an error.

This patch refactors the existing test, covering a few more different
cases with english and non-english locales. The last test currently
fails on master with an UnicodeDecodeError; this is fixed by the gettext
decoding.

Closes-Bug: 1580678
Change-Id: Ia82b3643a4c4edf329c4f7a2b05638f9de962c05

commit_message:
Ensure that the zuul home can be traversed

The default permissions for the zuul home directory
are not the same in the various distributions.
As /home/zuul contains the sources, a 700 default may be
problematic when accessing those files, so make sure
that the executable permissions are set.

Closes-Bug: 1846251
Change-Id: Ic9769e56274d7205844b86d3b5200a6415e4acad
(cherry picked from commit c67a689fe56f55fa3cd288fba76f88d3aa5b9b8d)

commit_message:
Cleanup for Refactor-error-messages

This patch is a clean-up patch for refactor-error-messages bp
which remove the exception message from base message otherwise
the same exception message display twice like
this https://ibb.co/XyFWMdz .

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/708069/
Change-Id: I89df4b9681da759ba5a5b898f1de63e85351bbce

commit_message:
Explicitly set jobs to ML2/OVS

Devstack is changing the Neutron default to OVN backend. This patch is
to make sure Ironic (and related projects) gate will not get broken by
this change as currently OVN doesn't support baremetal nodes.

Change-Id: Ib4e1624ef03f4dc73db435bb12bdd9f687dd3c02
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

recheck'}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2020-09-03 07:18:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

Was that ever working?'}, {'account_id': 23567, 'date': '2020-09-03 07:55:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

Umm, was that missing only on updates of the service? Is it supported to change the loadBalancerIP once created? Or on the other hand this could happen due to the CRD being created first due to the endpoints being created, and then the service gets created (with the loadbalancer IP) and the CRD update is missing that loadbalancer IP field on the upgrade.'}, {'account_id': 27032, 'date': '2020-09-03 08:04:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Umm, was that missing only on updates of the service? Is it
 > supported to change the loadBalancerIP once created? Or on the
 > other hand this could happen due to the CRD being created first due
 > to the endpoints being created, and then the service gets created
 > (with the loadbalancer IP) and the CRD update is missing that
 > loadbalancer IP field on the upgrade.

Exactly, this happened due to the second point you mentioned. Endpoints creating the crd and then svc handler updating it as was already existent.'}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2020-09-03 08:11:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

Hm, Luis provoked me to check K8s API spec:

> loadBalancerIP string
> Only applies to Service Type: LoadBalancer LoadBalancer will get created with the IP specified in this field. This feature depends on whether the underlying cloud-provider supports specifying the loadBalancerIP when a load balancer is created. This field will be ignored if the cloud-provider does not support the feature.

Is this how it's going to work?"}, {'account_id': 27032, 'date': '2020-09-03 08:16:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Hm, Luis provoked me to check K8s API spec:
 > 
 > > loadBalancerIP string
 > > Only applies to Service Type: LoadBalancer LoadBalancer will get
 > created with the IP specified in this field. This feature depends
 > on whether the underlying cloud-provider supports specifying the
 > loadBalancerIP when a load balancer is created. This field will be
 > ignored if the cloud-provider does not support the feature.
 > 
 > Is this how it's going to work?

If the specified ip it's really an existing floating ip on the osp tenant then it will get associated to the lb port, otherwise it's ignored and not used. 

https://github.com/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/1b99b1170ca3d48ba9764bb045a197ea9859365b/kuryr_kubernetes/controller/drivers/public_ip.py#L93"}, {'account_id': 32029, 'date': '2020-09-03 08:45:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2020-09-03 08:52:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Okay, good!'}]

[{'created': '2020-09-02 10:29:58.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure loadBalancerIP is used when defined on the Service

If a loadBalancerIP is defined on the Service it should be used
on the created Load Balancer. However, that is not happening as
the LB CRD can be missing the lb_ip field  definition, consequently
a new Floating IP is allocated to the Load Balancer. This commit
fixes the issue by ensuring the lb_ip is present on the CRD if
defined on the Service.

Change-Id: Ie626328972587772dbeeaf52f96b312de41026f2
'}, {'created': '2020-09-02 10:36:58.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure loadBalancerIP is used when defined on the Service

If a loadBalancerIP is defined on the Service it should be used
on the created Load Balancer. However, that is not happening as
the LB CRD can be missing the lb_ip field  definition, consequently
a new Floating IP is allocated to the Load Balancer. This commit
fixes the issue by ensuring the lb_ip is present on the CRD if
defined on the Service.

Closes-Bug: 1893927
Change-Id: Ie626328972587772dbeeaf52f96b312de41026f2

commit_message:
Ensure loadBalancerIP is used when defined on the Service

If a loadBalancerIP is defined on the Service it should be used
on the created Load Balancer. However, that is not happening as
the LB CRD can be missing the lb_ip field  definition, consequently
a new Floating IP is allocated to the Load Balancer. This commit
fixes the issue by ensuring the lb_ip is present on the CRD if
defined on the Service.

Closes-Bug: 1893927
Change-Id: Ie626328972587772dbeeaf52f96b312de41026f2

[{'created': '2020-09-02 19:08:28.000000000', 'message': '[CI] Fix Bifrost CentOS 8 job

This job was introduced as voting but never enabled in
Kolla-Ansible CI.
However, it sneaked into Kolla CI [1] causing breakage.

This patch makes it non-voting and actually runnable in
Kolla-Ansible CI.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/713509

Change-Id: I24444095643bf7ed4b0868b4509a10a93f3a0131
Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/749534
'}]
commit_message:
[CI] Fix Bifrost CentOS 8 job

This job was introduced as voting but never enabled in
Kolla-Ansible CI.
However, it sneaked into Kolla CI [1] causing breakage.

This patch makes it non-voting and actually runnable in
Kolla-Ansible CI.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/713509

Change-Id: I24444095643bf7ed4b0868b4509a10a93f3a0131
Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/749534

commit_message:
Reject resize operation for accelerator

When resize with a new flavor with accelerator, we should raise
forbidden exception to reject the resize operation.
Add related unit test.
Follow up the comment:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/715326/22/nova/compute/api.py@3907

Conflicts:
  nova/compute/api.py
  nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_api.py

NOTE(brinzhang): Conflicts are due to change
eef4b5435e7cdfe53ee9d9265d96c7dd278d9e93 ("api: Reject
non-spawn operations for vTPM") which modified the same code.

Co-Authored-By: Wenping Song <songwenping@inspur.com>
Closes-Bug: #1893751

Change-Id: I74d3402d564abd5b042024d59c7a55511afa6bf9

commit_message:
release oslo.messaging 12.1.4 - 2020-09-01

I released a bugfix version even if a new option have been added [1]
because 12.2.x is already consumed by victoria.

Although this adds a new option, it's just a gate on a
bug fix to ensure we don't have unintended side effects. That actually
makes this backport safer than if it just unconditionally enabled the
fix.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/747366/

Change-Id: Ifed5068d5762d241233e84bf419d586f9a2b39ed

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-08-27 08:51:08.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Support file:/// images for the direct deploy

Implemented via the same mechanism as for image_download_source=http.
Forcing raw format (and thus streaming) is supported as well.

Change-Id: Ife385c3b363c28559c90e5a54e9c6f6807d207ff
Story: #2008075
Task: #40764
'}, {'created': '2020-08-27 15:29:34.000000000', 'message': 'Support file:/// images for the direct deploy

Implemented via the same mechanism as for image_download_source=http.
Forcing raw format (and thus streaming) is supported as well.

commit_message:
Support file:/// images for the direct deploy

Implemented via the same mechanism as for image_download_source=http.
Forcing raw format (and thus streaming) is supported as well.

Since we always re-calculate checksums for such images, the requirement
on providing them via the API is lifted.

Change-Id: Ife385c3b363c28559c90e5a54e9c6f6807d207ff
Story: #2008075
Task: #40764

commit_message:
Make WSGI server respect listen_* directives

The listen_port and listen_host directives are intended to allow
deployers of IPA to change the port and host IPA listens on. These
configs have not been obeyed since the migration to the oslo.service
wsgi server.

Story: 2008016
Task: 40668
Change-Id: I76235a6e6ffdf80a0f5476f577b055223cdf1585
(cherry picked from commit 7d0ad36ebd350a7162bc3c33bbefd26b9e962a78)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-08-26 09:47:25.000000000', 'message': 'Update 10-kuryr.conf to 10-kuryr.conflist, and generate the 10-kuryr.conflist file from the template file kuryr.conflist.template

1.
Currently kubelet's cni config file uses 10-kuryr.conf in kuryr.
The kubernetes can support the config file with two suffixes, ".conf" and ".conflist", the latter can be a list containing multiple cni plugins.
So I want to update the 10-kuryr.conf to 10-kuryr.conflist to satisfy the need to use multiple plug-in support.

2.
If I install the kuryr-cni by pod, the 10-kuryr.conf will only be copied and overwrited from the kuryr/cni image container.
What I expected is we can customize the config file more freely.
So I think we can add an other file kuryr.conflist.template as the template, then we generate the 10-kuryr.conflist fron it.

Change-Id: Ie3669db4e60a57b24012124cd24b524eb03f55cf

commit_message:
Update 10-kuryr.conf to 10-kuryr.conflist, and generate the
10-kuryr.conflist file from the template file kuryr.conflist.template

1. Currently kubelet's cni config file uses 10-kuryr.conf in kuryr. The
kubernetes can support the config file with two suffixes, ".conf" and
".conflist", the latter can be a list containing multiple cni plugins.
So I want to update the 10-kuryr.conf to 10-kuryr.conflist to satisfy
the need to use multiple plug-in support.

2. If I install the kuryr-cni by pod, the 10-kuryr.conf will only be
copied and overwrited from the kuryr/cni image container. What I
expected is we can customize the config file more freely. So I think we
can add an other file kuryr.conflist.template as the template, then we
generate the 10-kuryr.conflist fron it.

Change-Id: Ie3669db4e60a57b24012124cd24b524eb03f55cf

commit_message:
Skip FIP creation if no external subnet config is set

When creating a Service of LoadBalancer type, a external_svc_net
config must be set, otherwise the Floating IP for the respective
LoadBalancer won't get created and an exception will be raised of
missing config. This commit logs and skip the FIP creation when
the needed config is not set.

Change-Id: I155d11f7080d2d4dbeca6de85b2f284aaacd7d8d

commit_message:
Remove no-op fake calls from network_info tests

Stephen pointed out during the review of
I4bdd25458998ca1a9fb411dfd015684a6d3fcfa3 that there are unnecessary
calls in the network_info unit tests. So this patch now drop these.

Change-Id: I5f9611e0d2eb212aaec299d27a4a29e6f7e3199c

will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/victoria

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/victoria branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I6155f95f9d8ef99c0d274d561f170a3c8ffa5c1b

commit_message:
Add note and daxio version to the vPMEM document

Make the spec of virtual persistent memory consistent with
the contents of the admin manual, update the dependency of virtual
persistent memory about daxio, and add NOTE for the tested kernel
version.

Closes-Bug: #1894022

Change-Id: I30539bb47c98a588b95c066a394949d60af9c520

commit_message:
Bring back allowed_direct_url_schemes in support of RBD image download

The options was deprecated but it has good use in configuration of the
direct RBD image download.

See the following blueprint for more details:

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/nova-image-download-via-rbd

Change-Id: I56a92dffec50f8c4051da26d6512dec3b2cc703b

commit_message:
Leverage the iSCSI mpath to get the WWN

Now that we search the multipath device even if we haven't been able to
find the WWN in the sysfs we can leverage the multipath daemon
information on sysfs to get the WWN.

Pass the mpath to "get_sysfs_wwn" method where we check the sysfs to get
the WWN.

Conflicts:
	os_brick/tests/initiator/connectors/test_iscsi.py
	os_brick/tests/initiator/test_linuxscsi.py
The tests required a few fixes to account for the differences between
the branches and the changes introduced by the backports this one
builds upon.

Change-Id: Id1905bc174b8f2f3a345664d8a0a05284ca69927
(cherry picked from commit 0cdd9bbbe29201942c9a296d6db2175452044689)
(cherry picked from commit 31c01b543cfe0219140e5bf9eaf703daa819de04)

(5 comments)

Just some small improvements. Why do we need to get the service in that method? Couldn't we save the SG onto the KLB itself in the Service handler?"}, {'account_id': 27032, 'date': '2020-09-02 08:22:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> (5 comments)
 > 
 > Just some small improvements. Why do we need to get the service in
 > that method? Couldn't we save the SG onto the KLB itself in the
 > Service handler?

Thanks for the review. The Service needs to be retrieved again because it's possible that the Pods selected by this Service were not created yet when the CRD got created and consequently it has empty sgs. So we need to retrieve again.
Note that this was how it was working before on 4.5 [1] but somehow it was missed on 4.6.

[1] https://github.com/openshift/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/release-4.5/kuryr_kubernetes/controller/handlers/lbaas.py#L303-L315"}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2020-09-02 08:26:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

 > empty sgs. So we need to retrieve again.

 > 
 > [1] https://github.com/openshift/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/release-4.5/kuryr_kubernetes/controller/handlers/lbaas.py#L303-L315

Alright, makes perfect sense! Please just fix the log messages then."}, {'account_id': 27032, 'date': '2020-09-02 08:33:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2020-09-02 09:03:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
Ensure LB sg is in sync with backend Pods

When a Service is created before the Pods, no security group to be
enforced on the Load Balancer exists as no matching Pod, which are
the ones providing the sgs, is present yet. Consequently, the LB
gets created with admin_state down due to no sg present and ACLs
blocking the traffic. This commit ensures the LB sg crd holds the
updated Pods' sg before enforcing them on the LB members.

Closes-Bug: 1893910
Change-Id: I9eb52a4d6b82d70493d109e9eb9be8706142bc7d

[{'account_id': 28332, 'date': '2020-09-01 08:53:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2020-09-01 08:57:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2020-09-01 09:04:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/749205/1 : FAILURE in 9m 13s'}, {'account_id': 28332, 'date': '2020-09-01 10:16:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2020-09-01 12:58:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 28332, 'date': '2020-09-01 14:41:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

To explain why we should may be use update instead of setdefaut():


Consider a boot from this image which is an instance snapshot:
$openstack image show 345f2397-40f5-40bd-8082-96e7074ffaa8 | grep -e properties
| properties       | base_image_ref='85bf4d72-1c46-43d8-bcb3-7ec9f7184575', ...
$openstack server create  --flavor m1.small --image 345f2397-40f5-40bd-8082-96e7074ffaa8  --nic net-id=private inst-from-snap

If I put a breakpoint in _populate_instance_for_create() when calling utils.get_system_metadata_from_image
> /opt/stack/nova/nova/compute/api.py(1895)_populate_instance_for_create()
-> system_meta = utils.get_system_metadata_from_image(image, instance_type)
(Pdb) n
> /opt/stack/nova/nova/compute/api.py(1899)_populate_instance_for_create()
-> system_meta.setdefault('image_base_image_ref', instance.image_ref)
(Pdb) p system_meta
{'image_base_image_ref': '85bf4d72-1c46-43d8-bcb3-7ec9f7184575', ......
(Pdb) p instance.image_ref
'345f2397-40f5-40bd-8082-96e7074ffaa8'
(Pdb) n
> /opt/stack/nova/nova/compute/api.py(1901)_populate_instance_for_create()
-> system_meta['owner_user_name'] = context.user_name
(Pdb) p system_meta
{'image_base_image_ref': '85bf4d72-1c46-43d8-bcb3-7ec9f7184575', .....

As you can see image_base_image_ref': '85bf4d72-1c46-43d8-bcb3-7ec9f7184575' exists before because inherit from image snapshot properties
And it did not have been updated to '345f2397-40f5-40bd-8082-96e7074ffaa8' as I think it should.
so setdefault did not update.
It is the same issue during rebuild that's why I preferer using update versus set_default() and probably we must consider changing also in _populate_instance_for_create during create to use also update ?

ofcourse set_default create the suitable entry when we boot from an image that is not a snapshot because property image_base_image_ref does not exists in image."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2020-09-02 08:26:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 13861, 'date': '2020-09-02 14:15:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

With this patch the failing jobs passes too https://review.rdoproject.org/r/#/c/29112/'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2020-09-02 14:19:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2020-09-02 14:46:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

(2 comments)

LGTM as a simple fix but there are some follow ups here that need to be addressed.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-09-02 15:44:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

recheck'}, {'account_id': 28332, 'date': '2020-09-02 19:10:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2020-09-02 20:02:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI, add a review comment with run-Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-09-01 08:53:57.000000000', 'message': 'Update image_base_image_ref during rebuild.

In different location we assume system_metadata.image_base_image_ref
exists, because it is set during instance creation in method
_populate_instance_for_create

But once instance is rebuild, all system_metadata image property a dropped
and replace by new image property and without setting back
image_base_image_ref.

This change propose to set image_base_image_ref during rebuild.

In specific case of shelve/unshelve in Qcow2 backend, image_base_image_ref is
used to rebase disk image, so we ensure this property is set as instance may
have been rebuild before the fix was apply.

Related-Bug: #1732428
Closes-Bug: #1893618
Change-Id: Ia3031ea1f7db8b398f02d2080ca603ded8970200
'}]
commit_message:
Update image_base_image_ref during rebuild.

In different location we assume system_metadata.image_base_image_ref
exists, because it is set during instance creation in method
_populate_instance_for_create

But once instance is rebuild, all system_metadata image property a dropped
and replace by new image property and without setting back
image_base_image_ref.

This change propose to set image_base_image_ref during rebuild.

In specific case of shelve/unshelve in Qcow2 backend, image_base_image_ref is
used to rebase disk image, so we ensure this property is set as instance may
have been rebuild before the fix was apply.

Related-Bug: #1732428
Closes-Bug: #1893618
Change-Id: Ia3031ea1f7db8b398f02d2080ca603ded8970200

[{'created': '2020-07-22 11:37:46.000000000', 'message': 'resolve ResourceProviderSyncFailed issue

This is caused by the "/" operation difference between python 2.x and python 3.x

In python 2.x "/" int / int returns int while
in python 3.x int / int return the real result.

Change-Id: I1aa96bdc2fdb2ca856b73b91e3120c75ec104537
'}]
commit_message:
resolve ResourceProviderSyncFailed issue

This is caused by the "/" operation difference between python 2.x and python 3.x

In python 2.x "/" int / int returns int while
in python 3.x int / int return the real result.

Change-Id: I1aa96bdc2fdb2ca856b73b91e3120c75ec104537

commit_message:
Set openstack namespace for victoria release onwards

https://review.opendev.org/747259 switches the container name
preffix to openstack for master.
In order to make it working for periodic jobs, we moved the var
to periodic release file at https://review.opendev.org/#/c/748690/
and for check one, it will take care.

Changes in container-build role takes care of provider job.

Closes-Bug: #1893339

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/747129/

Change-Id: I56b1570d7580c2592ff9948fae94c170db674a3f
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-09-01 14:58:42.000000000', 'message': 'Move pylint disable comment to an effective place

Bug #1893316 still occurs, e.g.:
https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/94dc9db2fee049b38926827e97bbec09

after the attempted fix:
https://review.opendev.org/748594

I believe the attempted fix was basically good, but in order to disable
the pylint warning for the whole method the comment must be placed
in the method body, not on the signature line.

Change-Id: I55c6daf976c62252aca403358b824d4d3aaa495c
Closes-Bug: #1893316
Related-Change: Iba4f2ea700f01fd153104741614eec4855d0f387
'}]
commit_message:
Move pylint disable comment to an effective place

Bug #1893316 still occurs, e.g.:
https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/94dc9db2fee049b38926827e97bbec09

after the attempted fix:
https://review.opendev.org/748594

I believe the attempted fix was basically good, but in order to disable
the pylint warning for the whole method the comment must be placed
in the method body, not on the signature line.

Change-Id: I55c6daf976c62252aca403358b824d4d3aaa495c
Closes-Bug: #1893316
Related-Change: Iba4f2ea700f01fd153104741614eec4855d0f387

commit_message:
Add ansible-collections for system-config -devel job

Ansible has split a lot of things out into collections; we can use
these in system config to test against when we're testing the devel
branch.

Change-Id: Icfef6929f6f903b97b780ffa372f1c4887903e6d

commit_message:
Move github reporting to checks API

This changes from the "status" API to the "checks" API, which puts
results on the "checks" tab on github.

This also puts a button to re-run failed tests, for which we need to
listen to the "check_run" event to handle.

Change-Id: I9cef46182f88f62daf5791594174a9af8c70a82f

commit_message:
Remove support for Intel CMT events

The 4.14 kernel is sufficiently old in the tooth (Ubuntu 18.04 uses
4.15, RHEL 7.x has likely backported the fixes) that there are likely
not a great deal of users that could still use this broken feature if
they wanted to. Drop support for it almost entirely, retaining only a
warning to prevent accidental use.

Change-Id: Iad76bce128574dc2f86998ccf2a9c5e799c71313
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Use container_file_t for Cinder*NfsMountOptions by default

This is so that share content is usable by cinder-volume and other
containers mounting the same share.

Closes-Bug: 1890291
Change-Id: Iacf7c9c368b26106e9921b35996c134aacb9acd7
(cherry picked from commit c7ec7262761d0a09287e9934fe36e3a068415807)

subject: Add ability to configure oslo_middleware
messages:
[{'account_id': 8064, 'date': '2020-08-18 23:20:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 16137, 'date': '2020-08-19 07:08:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Still curious if we really should start merging this new "params" approach, or would you like to create a plan (and blueprint/spec) and do this change across all modules next release? Given that all the details has been sorted out?'}, {'account_id': 8064, 'date': '2020-08-21 09:52:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't mind doing a spec. Before I do that, do you / cores think this is a good idea? Maybe we should discuss more, will IRC be a good place to get in touch?"}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2020-08-26 10:38:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Generally I would agree with the idea of params because it can save our maintenance effort.

However one problem with oslo_middlware configuration is that available parameters are different among some projects. For example Octavia has its own implementation to load oslo_middleware thus enable_proxy_hader_parsing is only a valid parameter if I'm not mistaken.
 https://review.opendev.org/#/c/736446/

IMO we should avoid from accepting invalid parameters in puppet layer, thus should use explicit parameters according to actual implementation, regarding oslo_middlware parameters."}, {'account_id': 8064, 'date': '2020-09-03 02:27:30.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Abandoning in favour of Change I59ce740ad85967e181da328e11d394cc1c029ab6'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-08-18 23:20:08.000000000', 'message': 'Add ability to configure oslo_middleware

Add a class oslo_middleware, which takes in a param hash to be passed to
the oslo::middleware class. This sets up the [oslo_middleware] config
section in magnum config.

This method makes it more generic; if oslo::middleware has a new param
we do not have to change it in all different projects. This is modelled
after Change-Id I695834ac03a52d8569e50db600676a89e165491d

Change-Id: I8556c9184a77473e319b6b99148b6d3793dc1988
'}]
commit_message:
Add ability to configure oslo_middleware

Add a class oslo_middleware, which takes in a param hash to be passed to
the oslo::middleware class. This sets up the [oslo_middleware] config
section in magnum config.

This method makes it more generic; if oslo::middleware has a new param
we do not have to change it in all different projects. This is modelled
after Change-Id I695834ac03a52d8569e50db600676a89e165491d

Change-Id: I8556c9184a77473e319b6b99148b6d3793dc1988

commit_message:
Remove Etcd from DCN roles that don't need it

Remove the Etcd service from DCN roles that do not need it. Etcd is
only required by the cinder-volume service in order to run in active/
active mode. Roles that do not host the cinder-volume service do not
need Etcd.

Change-Id: Ia24eed019ba973aad0e8f5b7fc0d53c1ee4149e8
(cherry picked from commit 500ba04798674ba487b370eb3a2c223cbaef9cd4)

[{'created': '2020-07-15 15:11:51.000000000', 'message': 'Add tripleo container image hotfix command

This change adds a CLI command to invoke hotfixes via the TripleO modify
image role. This CLI command will ensure a uniform experience for operators
when needing to apply a hotfixes to containers.

Change-Id: I364fb42a41b4cb4ae076f07704c72c6ea442a198

commit_message:
Add tripleo container image hotfix command

This change adds a CLI command to invoke hotfixes via the TripleO modify
image role. This CLI command will ensure a uniform experience for operators
when needing to apply a hotfixes to containers.

Change-Id: I364fb42a41b4cb4ae076f07704c72c6ea442a198
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 4967f4f6eec7de8745a43fb1cd73e56ccc50a6a1)
(cherry picked from commit 39c270006d98ec5a20992a575cd5a145762bc40d)
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
DCN: use FQDN in glance endpoint with internal TLS

Fix the glance-api endpoint used by cinder and nova services at DCN
sites. When internal TLS is enabled, the URI must use a FQDN and not
an IP address.

Closes-Bug: #1893453
Change-Id: I386a035f9688c54d617e714888c9c0fa14f34a1e
(cherry picked from commit 2035b88f5b9eb1c86391c995f768f9ecc45855a4)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-08-21 18:57:49.000000000', 'message': "Don't directly access the in-memory DB for NB_Global row

Directly accessing the in-memory OVSDB via 'tables' outside of a
Command object isn't safe. For example, if we lose connection to
the OVSDB and reconnect, the in-memory copy will be replaced by
the Connection thread. If we get a call to get_agents() that is
handled by the main thread and we look up the value from there,
the value we expect may be missing.

The dependent patch in ovsdbapp adds some locking to help with
this some API commands like lookup() that are heavily used and
with ReadOnlyCommands which also aren't processed like normal
Command objects inside the connection thread.

There will be many more changes in the ml2/ovn code similar to
this one, as we directly access the in-memory copy a lot.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/745746/
Change-Id: I328391c88af1ef2f6b1af3787c63d8591fb317b5
Closes-Bug: #1888878

commit_message:
Don't directly access the in-memory DB for NB_Global row

Directly accessing the in-memory OVSDB via 'tables' outside of a
Command object isn't safe. For example, if we lose connection to
the OVSDB and reconnect, the in-memory copy will be replaced by
the Connection thread. If we get a call to get_agents() that is
handled by the main thread and we look up the value from there,
the value we expect may be missing.

The dependent patch in ovsdbapp adds some locking to help with
this some API commands like lookup() that are heavily used and
with ReadOnlyCommands which also aren't processed like normal
Command objects inside the connection thread.

There will be many more changes in the ml2/ovn code similar to
this one, as we directly access the in-memory copy a lot.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/745746/
Change-Id: I328391c88af1ef2f6b1af3787c63d8591fb317b5
Closes-Bug: #1888878

Looks like I might need those changes to utils.py after all. `kill -TERM`ing a worker doesn't end well:

Aug 21 03:54:37 saio object-6030: Removing dead child 13474 from parent 13317

  File "/vagrant/swift/swift/common/utils.py", line 2513, in <listcomp>
    stdio_files = [f for f in stdio_files if f.fileno() not in console_fds]
AttributeError: 'LoggerFileObject' object has no attribute 'fileno'
Aug 21 03:54:37 saio object-6030: UNCAUGHT EXCEPTION
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/swift-object-server", line 7, in <module>

    **options))

    'worker did not start normally: %r' % worker_status)
Exception: worker did not start normally: b''

Work distribution still looks good, though!'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-08-21 05:08:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2020-08-25 22:37:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

(38 comments)

ok, it only took most of a day but I really feel like I understand this code!  (sorry for all the comments)

My understanding of the motivation of the change is this is something we will HAVE to do.  Moreover *this* change (as-is) seems to get the job done!  It's certainly not not horribly broken in the "did you even run this" sense.  I even had a few WTF moments that eventually became clear the code is already doing the right thing - I have a suspicion it's fairly robust as well effective!    Never-the-less I'm not I'm not quite ready to be the sole +A

First, I haven't looked at tests (gotta cook dinner).  Also there's two behaviors I'd like to test functionally:

1) how did we and now how do we fail when trying to bind to privileged ports when starting as an unprivileged user (particularly in the proxy worker strategy more so than someone putting port 80 in their rings)

2) how does the multi-worker ready pipe signaling behave with LOTS of workers (esp if we artificially make some of them slow or break the write('ready') into multiple calls because I forget what sort of guarantees pipes have a about transmission and read length and flush and close

Beyond that I have some nagging itch that we might be able to forget about sockets after we hand them off to workers and simplify some bookkeepping.

But none of these questions should be considered blockers, I'll keep chugging at it.  I know Tim has already run this in some production contexts - I don't want to hold up the show.  In fact getting rid of PortPidState might be worth merging it just in principle!'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-08-25 23:32:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(17 comments)

I might try a respin that keeps do_bind_ports around... and re-use sockets for respawned children...'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2020-08-26 19:33:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

(4 comments)

Ok, I don't have any reservations on this anymore

we're doing all the socket validation stuff before we close stdio

i was just confused about the pipe-per-worker; that stuff is solid (and fast).

I was gunna +A but I see it's on todays meeting; so i'll just wait till then.

NICE WORK TIM!"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-09-02 18:15:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

So looking ahead to something like https://review.opendev.org/#/c/748721/, maybe we *do* want to keep do_bind_ports...'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2020-09-02 21:34:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Bind a new socket per-worker

We've seen lumpy distributions of requests to workers, which seems to
parallel what some other projects have seen [0][1].

The solution (as best we can tell) is to take advantage of the
SO_REUSEPORT that eventlet's been setting for us since basically
forever [2].

[0] https://lwn.net/Articles/542629/
[1] https://github.com/varnish/hitch/issues/142
[2] https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/commit/f9a3074a3

commit_message:
Update master for stable/victoria

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/victoria.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/victoria.

Change-Id: I7eba32adc5897940ceb712561ee40327e0f2418f
Sem-Ver: feature

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-08-27 17:32:04.000000000', 'message': "compute: Don't delete the original attachment during pre LM rollback

I0bfb11296430dfffe9b091ae7c3a793617bd9d0d introduced support for live
migration with cinderv3 volume attachments during Queens. This initial
support handled failures in pre_live_migration directly by removing any
attachments created on the destination and reverting to the original
attachment ids before re-raising the caught exception to the source
compute. It also added rollback code within the main
_rollback_live_migration method but missed that this would also be
called during a pre_live_migration rollback.

As a result after a failure in pre_live_migration
_rollback_live_migration will attempt to delete the source host volume
attachments referenced by the bdm before updating the bdms with the now
non-existent attachment ids, leaving the volumes in an `available` state
in Cinder as they have no attachment records associated with them
anymore.

This change aims to resolve this within _rollback_volume_bdms by
ensuring that the current and original attachment_ids are not equal
before requesting that the current attachment referenced by the bdm is
deleted. When called after a failure in pre_live_migration this should
result in no attempt being made to remove the original source host
attachments from Cinder.

Note that the following changes muddy the waters slightly here but
introduced no actual changes to the logic within
_rollback_live_migration:

* I0f3ab6604d8b79bdb75cf67571e359cfecc039d8 reworked some of the error
  handling in Rocky but isn't the source of the issue here.

* Ibe9215c07a1ee00e0e121c69bcf7ee1b1b80fae0 reworked
  _rollback_live_migration to use the provided source_bdms.

* I6bc73e8c8f98d9955f33f309beb8a7c56981b553 then refactored
  _rollback_live_migration, moving the logic into a self contained
  _rollback_volume_bdms method.

Closes-Bug: #1889108
Change-Id: I9edb36c4df1cc0d8b529e669f06540de71766085
(cherry picked from commit 2102f1834a6ac9fd870bfb457b28a2172f33e281)
(cherry picked from commit 034b2fa8fea0e34fed95a2ba728e4387ce4e78de)

* Ibe9215c07a1ee00e0e121c69bcf7ee1b1b80fae0 reworked

commit_message:
compute: Don't delete the original attachment during pre LM rollback

I0bfb11296430dfffe9b091ae7c3a793617bd9d0d introduced support for live
migration with cinderv3 volume attachments during Queens. This initial
support handled failures in pre_live_migration directly by removing any
attachments created on the destination and reverting to the original
attachment ids before re-raising the caught exception to the source
compute. It also added rollback code within the main
_rollback_live_migration method but missed that this would also be
called during a pre_live_migration rollback.

As a result after a failure in pre_live_migration
_rollback_live_migration will attempt to delete the source host volume
attachments referenced by the bdm before updating the bdms with the now
non-existent attachment ids, leaving the volumes in an `available` state
in Cinder as they have no attachment records associated with them
anymore.

This change aims to resolve this within _rollback_volume_bdms by
ensuring that the current and original attachment_ids are not equal
before requesting that the current attachment referenced by the bdm is
deleted. When called after a failure in pre_live_migration this should
result in no attempt being made to remove the original source host
attachments from Cinder.

Note that the following changes muddy the waters slightly here but
introduced no actual changes to the logic within
_rollback_live_migration:

* I0f3ab6604d8b79bdb75cf67571e359cfecc039d8 reworked some of the error
  handling in Rocky but isn't the source of the issue here.

* Ibe9215c07a1ee00e0e121c69bcf7ee1b1b80fae0 reworked
  _rollback_live_migration to use the provided source_bdms.

* I6bc73e8c8f98d9955f33f309beb8a7c56981b553 then refactored
  _rollback_live_migration, moving the logic into a self contained
  _rollback_volume_bdms method.

Closes-Bug: #1889108
Change-Id: I9edb36c4df1cc0d8b529e669f06540de71766085
(cherry picked from commit 2102f1834a6ac9fd870bfb457b28a2172f33e281)
(cherry picked from commit 034b2fa8fea0e34fed95a2ba728e4387ce4e78de)

commit_message:
compute: refactor volume bdm rollback error handling

Previously any exception while rolling back the connection_info and
attachment_id of volume bdms would result in the overall attempt to
rollback a LM failing. This change refactors this specific bdm rollback
logic into two self contained methods that ignore by default errors
where possible to allow the LM rollback attempt to continue.

Change-Id: I6bc73e8c8f98d9955f33f309beb8a7c56981b553
(cherry picked from commit 9524a5a1b5745f6064f88cbfbf5bbfae3a973bef)
